title: Set apart from the herd
text:
Maybe you're lonely but not desperate. You are a woman seeking a man set apart from the herd. You, like me, are hoping to discover a beautiful person on the inside, not just an attractive appearance. To connect with on a deeply meaningful level.

You're not jaded and don't have a set of criterion or tests for a match. You'll know it when it happens and you'll see it coming. You're affectionate and love to get cozy next to someone. You like to talk and text. You realize that relationships take work and time and are willing to dedicate some time to ours. You value honor, truth, trust, and respect; all of which are important in communication. Your intention is to begin as friends because if we can't do that, we're not going to last.

title: Humanist, Horny and Hatin' on NYC Dating Scene Seeks Same
text:
Hi there. I'm in a wild mood tonight, which either makes this the perfect time or the worst time to post a personal ad. But I'm gonna give it a shot.

I'll start with a quick introduction to me. I'm a brown-eyed and -haired nonprofit fundraiser with a youthful appearance and a fondness for Japanese culture. I take life as slowly as possible, relish both high and low culture, and enjoy telling crazy stories about my experiences (which are unfortunately true). I'm also a funny guy, a popular figure in my office(s), and nearly clever enough to be the love child of Dr. Doom and Judit Polgar. Lastly, 87% of surveyed women between the ages of 19 and 42 have informed me that I'm "surprisingly" good at sex, which is a backhanded compliment I'm more than willing to accept! 

So, not that you need to know this, but I also use OKCupid for dating purposes. And I marvel at the sheer number of profiles there that wax poetic about how wonderful NYC is. I'm native to the city, and while I love the cultural opportunities here, I also hate many things about the Big Apple - with the dating scene rising to the top of my shit list.

Indeed, I half-suspect that the Borg took over NYC 20 years ago, because I'm consistently amazed by the dullness and conformity of almost everyone I date (or even just meet) here. By the time I've passed on all the corporate drones and arrogant would-be artists, who's left for me to fall in love with? (And yes, I'm aware that women have a lousy selection of men to choose from, too.) Given that NYC is the cultural capital of America, why does everyone here talk about nothing more interesting than work, the gym, football or the latest "sophisticated" cable TV show about a middle-aged white male consolidating his personal empire while having lots of doggie-style sex? Fuck me, where are the free thinkers around here?

That's really who I want to meet - a free thinker. And I don't care if you're not physically perfect. I'm not either - after all, no one who looks like George Clooney or Fabio would post an ad like this. In my favor, I have a rather cute look; and I've aged so well that contemporaries who used to be more attractive than me now look way worse! My Achilles heel is that I need to lose weight, but the Earth doesn't tremble at my approach or anything like that. 

Perhaps you're not skinny, too? That's fine. Nothing would make me happier than to while away a pleasant four hours watching the Kenneth Branagh Hamlet with you - and then spend the next four hours worshipping your big, beautiful butt. Indeed, that's my idea of a perfect Sunday. And no, I don't care what race you are (why are there so many racists online?!), what belief systems you hold, or what you do for a living. If you're a good person, and you fit my unusually broad definition of attractiveness, I'm all yours.

If all that sounds you-ish, drop me a line - and I'll buy you a drink sometime very soon, instead of emailing you to death. Please *don't* respond if: you don't like this ad and simply want to criticize me (in which case you can sod off in advance); you're married (there's a "casual encounters" section for that); or there's some huge age gap between us. For some reason college students keep answering my ads, and while they claim to be open-minded about dating a dude old enough to be their dad, in the end they...totally aren't. If you're a college student, please think it over at least 10 times before replying.

More importantly...thanks for reading this far. Really. :-)

P.S. - In person, I'm more positive than you might think based on this ad. Though my dating life is full of horror stories that would turn Stephen King's hair white (if it isn't already), I remain open-hearted, and I give each new fruitloop I meet a real chance! I hope you'll give me a real chance too.

title: Brains + Compassion + Respect = ?
text:
So, I was reading the Metro "news"paper the other day, and there was a pretty interesting column by a dating expert. This columnist argued that people tend to look for love in the wrong ways -- e.g., by going to bars (which she described as her "least recommended" place to meet people), or by judging prospective mates exclusively by their looks instead of personality and character. She concluded by advising people not to limit their dating choices to certain physical types, and to instead apply more serious criteria to choosing their lifemates. Well, duh, right?

I suppose this column resonated with me because, now that I'm 36 and (somewhat) evolved beyond horny teenager mode, I find myself craving contact with good, compassionate, and intelligent people (instead of colorful, hot, and dangerous people). When I think about what I want from my next relationship, words like "respect" pop into my head, as in "I want to wake up next to someone I respect." This does not mean I'm not interested in hot sex; it means I want to have hot sex with someone who appeals to my heart and my brain, in addition to my crotch. Pheromones are nice and all, but they ain't the boss of me anymore.

In a sense, I want to set the clock back to my pleasantly naive youth. Back in college, I actually enjoyed dating, because many college students are still idealistic enough to fall in love over shared enthusiasm for art, knowledge, principles, etc. Something changed as I got older, though. After I hit 25 or thereabouts, nobody I dated seemed to care about ideas anymore. Money and harsh standards of physical fitness, among other boring things, became more important to people than anything else. My dates became less like adventures and more like a grinding series of job interviews.

But even after years of enduring this sucky trend, I still retain a cinder of hope that, if I spam a site like Craig's List with thoughtful personal ads, I will receive the right response from the right person. But why I remain optimistic, I have no idea. My Internet dates get weirder and more alienating with each passing year, while my recent romantic successes have all come from doing "real world" stuff like going to parties and traveling abroad. But old habits die hard, and I dislike failing at things, so I'm always ready to give Internet dating another whirl.

In case I haven't been clear, I'm looking to meet someone intelligent, compassionate, open, and un-cynical. Everything else is unimportant window dressing. Yes, some attraction is necessary -- and I'm nowhere near as ugly as I'm making myself sound -- but attraction takes many forms, and cannot be predicted by email correspondence or by looking at JPEGs. The idea is to meet in real life and look for a real connection. Of hookups, I've had enough; of soulmates, I haven't had nearly enough.

title: Is it Really Cheating if you have no Choice?
text:
You're not responsible for what happened, I mean you're really, truly not. You were restless and stressed and feeling something you can barely explain or define. You just needed to talk to somebody, to blow off some steam, to just do something different for one evening. Something exciting, but nothing wrong or dirty. And absolutely not cheating. 

You were clear about your status in all your emails, it's all there in black and white. You never pretended you were looking for a fling or a one night stand, quite the opposite: you said you're involved and you're not looking to fool around. You said it, you meant it, and you never once said anything different, or even thought anything different. That's the absolute truth. 

Really. Really and truly. 

I mean suppose there's an awful kind of man who just won't take a firm, honest no for an answer. Suppose there's an awful kind of man who can trick a curious, restless but faithful girl into coming back to his place, just to talk a little more openly and not have to whisper. Just to help her work things out, since she knows he's so experienced and he really has talked to so many girls who are going through exactly the same kind of strange, restless, stressed phase a girl's in right now. 

How could she know? She's not the kind of girl who associates with this kind of man. She's honest and trusting and naive. 

And what if, hypothetically, at first it was just talk, just like it was supposed to be? And then he made her drink another drink and it was way too strong but she would have felt so uncomfortable to complain or refuse. And she knew that she had told him that she only wanted to talk, that she would never do anything beyond that, not one single thing. And he'd agreed, hadn't he? He'd agreed. 

So when he sat right next to her, she pulled away as much as she could. And when he touched her arm, her hair, her waist, her cheek, she flinched and told him to stop. And when he held her head nice and tight and tasted her lips, she made sure she didn't kiss back. She never kissed back. 

She wanted to go, but he held her. She wanted her clothes on, but he stripped them off until she was naked. Embarrassing though her plight was, she still would have screamed, but when he saw her draw breath he clamped his big hand over her mouth. 

He never once asked her, and he never once gave her a chance to stop things, or even a chance to get away. He got her right where he wanted her, held her down with his big strong hands, and used her exactly how he wanted, all for his own pleasure. More than once. 

Afterwards he told her he liked her so much that she'd have to keep coming back, surrendering herself to him again and again. How could she refuse, not knowing what he might be capable of? What choice would a girl have in that situation? 

So it wasn't your fault. And would you really even call that cheating?

You can sleep together on the first date, you don't have to stay over, nobody gets upset if you have other plans of a Friday night, and it's totally cool to send a buzzed, and thoughtful text aimed at getting laid at midnight on a Saturday.

title: Am I the only one..
text:
Thought I'd post this again and see if maybe this time someone 100% genuine would respond.

Am I the only one who feels unappreciated? You treat those you care for extremely well, you're there for them 100%. Yet.. no ones there for you.. I've been trying to expand my social circle. I meet new people and exchange numbers just about every other day. Yet when I reach out to them, they never answer back.. I've been told more than once it's a New York thing.. Why does it seem impossible for me to have people around me who are genuinely here for me, that want to be around me.. That are willing to hangout and go out of their way, just to see me.. It doesn't seem like anyone I've met understands me. Despite me being social, friendly, honest and caring. I'm also pretty strong minded, I don't follow crowds, I'm not big on social media. So when placed in a group I usually stand out like a sore thumb. I've begun thinking NY probably isn't the right place for me to find the things I want.. The things I need.. I mean.. I'm my own boss, I make my own schedule every week. So I have more free time than anyone I know and I make more money then most of them too. I'm a gamer. A anime fan. 5'10. I have one of the best set ups for kicking back and watching movies. I love cuddling too. My taste in music goes across the board. I enjoy pleasing others but have learned I have to reserve that for only those I feel are worth it. I'm pretty much always told me hands are divine. That my massages are amazing. In my lifetime I've actually had multiple people reach back out to me just for a massage.. Like really.. I enjoy going out and spontaneously doing things from time to time. I value the smaller things in life that people take for granted. I bet by now, the question of.. How is it someone like him is having such a hard time. Well I am of the darker color. If you know what I mean. I am a nerd at heart, yet at the same time I love certain sports and working with my hands. I am well spoken, which surprises people for some odd reason. I am very much a big kid at heart, even though it may not seem like it. I am who I am.. So why is it so hard to be excepted by others..
